docs.lead_paragraph: The Old Westbury Golf and Country Club luxuriates on the rolling hills of this Gold Coast village, where wealth and seclusion are signified by private roads lined with iron gates, mansions and bridle paths. But on the fairway and inside the elegant brick clubhouse, gentlemanly decorum has ruptured in recent years. Against a backdrop of marble fireplaces, period furniture and paintings of fox hunts, snarling club members have called one another liars and thieves. More than once, members have lunged at and tried to choke each other.

headline.main: Multimillion-Dollar Ponzi Scheme Roils a Long Island Country Club

docs.lead_paragraph: Last August, while eating breakfast on a family vacation in Idaho, Pat O'Connor, chief of staff to the Assembly Democratic leader, Joseph V. Doria of Bayonne, opened up a newspaper. Oregon, he read, had just passed a law banning health insurance companies from using information that turns up in genetic tests to set rates or deny coverage. "I said, 'Gee, what a great idea for New Jersey,' " Mr. O'Connor recalled last week. " 'Joe would be a great guy to do it.' "

headline.main: Just You and Your DNA: How the System Worked to Insure Genetic Privacy

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The defeat of campaign finance reform in Congress and the Supreme Court angered me (front page, June 26, and editorial, June 27). Why do Americans not bother to vote? A major cause is the belief that elections are controlled by the wealthy. The failure to achieve campaign finance reform just confirms that conviction.

headline.main: Campaign Financing Bill Deserves Oblivion;What Voters Can Do
